Films

Get the spring 2008 film guide here!

War Dance

War Dance// Thursday May 22 (tonight), 7PM and 10PM // Free at Swift room 107

Academy Award Nominee for Best Documentary Feature

Sean Fine and Andrea Nix Fine’s WAR DANCE is a powerful documentary that follows a group of schoolchildren as they overcome nearly insurmountable odds in their quest to participate in the annual Kampala Music Festival. For over 20 years, Northern Uganda has been a war zone, and as a vicious rebel force, the Lord’s Resistance Army, has run rampant, destroying villages, kidnapping children, and murdering parents. The 60,000 survivors are forced to live in a refugee camp, where conditions are bleak and resources are scarce. Somehow, the children of the Patongo Primary School have qualified for the Kampala Music Festival competition for the first time, a feat unto itself; yet these children are determined to take home the championship prize. As they make their way to Kampala to perform in front of an audience that doesn’t think much of them, they must band together to prove that war and famine and slaughter cannot suffocate their spirit.

http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/war_dance/#synopsis

The Lion King Sing-Along!

A&O and Mayfest present The Lion King!

The childhood classic….in sing-along form!
Tuesday, May 20th at 9PM on the Norris Lawn!

The Lion King? Sing along? Yeah, that’s right. Belt out "Nants ingonyama bagithi baba" with Rafiki ("Circle of Life", anyone?) or just chill on the lawn and enjoy this Disney classic for the self-conscious tone deaf. No matter what, the Lion King is sure to bring you back to the good ol’ grade school days when you still believed in Hakuna Matata. Lion nuzzling is encouraged but not condoned.

A&O Films Special Event: PANGEA DAY

"Pangea Day is a global event bringing the world together through film."

This will be a truly unique experience and the first time A&O has brought something like this to campus. It is a film festival being broadcast around the world at a number of satellite locations including Northwestern’s campus. Significant talent is behind the event, as the advisory board for Pangea Day contains such names as J.J. Abrams, Meg Ryan, Cameron Diaz, Paul Simon, Forest Whitaker, and others. Come anytime for FREE to McCormick Auditorium on Saturday May 10th from 1-5PM and enjoy this incredible cultural opportunity and celebration of film.

For more information:
http://www.pangeaday.org/

No Country for Old Men & The Savages

No Country for Old Men // Friday April 25 & Saturday April 26, 7PM and 10PM // $3 in McCormick Auditorium

The Coen brothers make their finest thriller since Fargo with a restrained adaptation of Cormac McCarthy’s novel. Not that there aren’t moments of intense violence, but No Country for Old Men is their quietest, most existential film yet. In this modern-day Western, Llewelyn Moss (Josh Brolin) is a Vietnam vet who could use a break. He finds a case filled with $2 million and Moss takes it with him and hits the road only to discover he’s being followed by ex-special ops agent Chigurh (an eerily calm Javier Bardem). Like the taciturn terminator, No Country for Old Men doesn’t move quickly, but the tension never dissipates.

The Savages // Sunday April 27, 7:30PM, FREE in Harris 107

 Jon (Philip Seymour Hoffman) and Wendy Savage (Laura Linney) are two siblings who have spent their adult years trying to recover from the memory of their abusive father. Suddenly, a call comes in that Lenny’s girlfriend has died and he cannot care for himself. Despite the fact Jon and Wendy have not spoken to Lenny for twenty years, the Savage siblings feel obliged to take care of him. As Wendy and Jon struggle to make some kind of peace with their difficult father, watching these wonderfully understated yet compelling actors is a pleasure unto itself.

Eastern Promises and Once

Eastern Promises / Friday March 14 & Saturday March 15 / 7PM and 10PM, $3 in McCormick Auditorium

This compelling thriller focuses on a London midwife (Naomi Watts) whose investigation of the death of a patient puts her in the sights of a Russian mobster (Oscar nominee Viggo Mortenson). From Director David Cronenberg, Eastern Promises takes place in the grainy underworld of the Russian Mafia and delves deep into the mystery of human nature.

Once / Sunday March 16 / 7:30PM, FREE in Harris 107

This musical tells the story of two struggling musicians in Dublin. A street performer draws the attention of a Czech immigrant, and the pair develop both musical and romantic connections. Wonderfully understated, Once has been hailed one of the best musicals in recent memory, and its song "Falling Slowly" won best original song in a motion picture in the 2008 Oscars.

Michael Clayton and This Is England

Michael Clayton // Friday February 22 and Saturday February 23 // 7PM & 10PM, $3 in McCormick Auditorium

Michael Clayton is an intriguing legal thriller. George Clooney stars as the title character, a crooked attorney known as a "fixer"– he constantly covers up other people’s mistakes, and makes a few of his own along the way. In the midst of corporate greed and a murder mystery, Clayton finds himself in a situation which desperately needs fixing. This movie is also a Best Picture Oscar nominee.

This is England // Sunday February 24 // 7:30PM, FREE in Harris 107

In this well-acted and cruel look at England in 1983, twelve-year-old street smart Shaun joins a group of older hoodlums. When the former leader of the gang gets out of jail and tries to lead them into battle against the immigrants who are taking away their jobs, Shaun must choose his path in this vicious and tough world.

The Darjeeling Limited and Paris Je T’aime

The Darjeeling Limited / FRIDAY February 15 only / 7PM and 10PM, $3 in McCormick Auditorium

In Wes Anderson’s latest film, three brothers (Owen Wilson, Adrien Brody, Jason Schwartzman) set off on a spiritual quest to bond in India. When things go wrong, they are forced to take a new and unplanned adventure and in the process both find themselves and reconnect with each other.

 

Paris Je T’aime / SUNDAY February 17 / 7:30PM, FREE in Harris 107

This romantic film is composed of a series of 18 love stories, each individually directed, which come together to focus on the diversity of relationships in the different neighborhoods of Paris. Directed by a collaboration of internationally-acclaimed filmmakers, the movie also features an impressive cast including Elijah Wood, Natalie Portman and Maggie Gyllenhaal.

FREE Sneak Preview: Charlie Bartlett

A&O Films Presents an Advanced Screening of:

Charlie Bartlett
Monday February 11 at 7:30PM
FREE in McCormick Auditorium

"Wealthy teenager Charlie Bartlett is failing miserably at fitting in at a new public high school run by the world-weary Principal Gardner. As he begins to better understand the social hierarchy, Charlie’s honest charm and likability positions him as the resident "psychiatrist" dishing out advice, and the occasional prescription with his partner and fellow student, Murphy Bivens, to other students in need. Along the way, he decides to take some of his own advice, find romance, and learn to accept who he is, thus wielding a witty dark comedy about the angst-filled years before college."

**Free passes available at Norris Box Office!**

 

American Ganster and Rocket Science

American Gangster / Friday Feb. 8 and Saturday Feb. 9 / 7:00 and 10:00, $3 in McCormick Auditorium

This critically-acclaimed drama from Ridley Scott tells the story of Harlem drug lord Frank Lucas (Denzel Washington) and the one cop savvy enough to take him down (Russell Crowe). The seasoned acting and accomplished direction make American Gangster a true contender during awards season- and one film you should not miss.

Rocket Science / Sunday Feb. 10 / 7:30PM, FREE in Harris 107

Another heartwarming "teen outsider" indie, this film follows the awkward existence of Hal, a student with an extreme stuttering problem. When his high school’s cute debate champion Ginny recruits him to be her debate partner, Hal must deal with his fear of public speaking and his growing affections for her.

 

Across the Universe and La Vie en Rose

Across the Universe / Friday Feb. 1 and Saturday Feb 2. / 7:00PM and 10:00PM, $3 in McCormick Auditorium

An original musical film based on the songs of the Beatles, Across the Universe is the fictional love story of Jude (Jim Sturgess) and Lucy (Evan Rachel Wood). Set in the 1960s amidst the turbulent years of anti-war protest, our characters must discover where they place importance in their lives. A combination of live action and animation paired with an amazing soundtrack, this Golden Globe-nominated film is not to be missed.

La Vie en Rose / Sunday Feb. 3 / 7:30PM, FREE in Harris 107

This poignant drama offers a glimpse into the troubled life of French singer Edith Piaf (Marillon Cotillard). Born into poverty, Piaf rose to become one of the most renowned performers in Paris- but not without paying the high price of fame. This film has been nominated for several awards, including the Oscar for Best Actress.
